The fragrant essential oil obtained chiefly from the Damask Rose is known as rose oil or attar of roses. It is a mixture of volatile essential oils obtained by steam distilling the crushed petals of roses. The production technique originated in Persia and then spread through Arabia and India, and more recently into eastern Europe. In Bulgaria, Iran, and Germany, damask roses ("Rosa" × "damascena" 'Trigintipetala') are used for extracting the oil. The oil is transparent pale yellow or yellow-grey in color, and the weight of oil extracted is about one three-thousandth to one six-thousandth of the weight of the flowers.
